segment.source: If you're looking for content on what each telemetry level means and how to configure it in your organization, see Configure Windows telemetry in your organization.
segment.target: If you're looking for content on what each telemetry level means and how to configure it in your organization, see Configure Windows telemetry in your organization.

segment.source: Learn about the network connections that Windows components make to Microsoft and also the privacy settings that affect data that is shared with either Microsoft or apps and how they can be managed by an IT Pro.
segment.target: Learn about the network connections that Windows components make to Microsoft and also the privacy settings that affect data that is shared with either Microsoft or apps and how they can be managed by an IT Pro.

segment.source: If you want to minimize connections from Windows to Microsoft services, or configure particular privacy settings, this article covers the settings that you could consider.
segment.target: If you want to minimize connections from Windows to Microsoft services, or configure particular privacy settings, this article covers the settings that you could consider.

segment.source: You can configure telemetry at the lowest level for your edition of Windows, and also evaluate which other connections Windows makes to Microsoft services you want to turn off in your environment from the list in this article.
segment.target: You can configure telemetry at the lowest level for your edition of Windows, and also evaluate which other connections Windows makes to Microsoft services you want to turn off in your environment from the list in this article.

segment.source: Some of the network connections discussed in this article can be managed in Windows 10 Mobile, Windows 10 Mobile Enterprise, and the July release of Windows 10.
segment.target: Some of the network connections discussed in this article can be managed in Windows 10 Mobile, Windows 10 Mobile Enterprise, and the July release of Windows 10.

segment.source: However, you must use Windows 10 Enterprise, version 1511 or Windows 10 Education, version 1511 to manage them all.
segment.target: However, you must use Windows 10 Enterprise, version 1511 or Windows 10 Education, version 1511 to manage them all.

segment.source: In Windows 10 Enterprise, version 1511 or Windows 10 Education, version 1511, you can configure telemetry at the Security level, turn off Windows Defender telemetry and MSRT reporting, and turn off all other connections to Microsoft services as described in this article to prevent Windows from sending any data to Microsoft.
segment.target: In Windows 10 Enterprise, version 1511 or Windows 10 Education, version 1511, you can configure telemetry at the Security level, turn off Windows Defender telemetry and MSRT reporting, and turn off all other connections to Microsoft services as described in this article to prevent Windows from sending any data to Microsoft.

segment.source: We strongly recommend against this, as this data helps us deliver a secure, reliable, and more delightful personalized experience.
segment.target: We strongly recommend against this, as this data helps us deliver a secure, reliable, and more delightful personalized experience.

segment.source: This section lists the components that make network connections to Microsoft services automatically.
segment.target: This section lists the components that make network connections to Microsoft services automatically.

segment.source: You can configure these settings to control the data that is sent to Microsoft.
segment.target: You can configure these settings to control the data that is sent to Microsoft.

segment.source: To prevent Windows from sending any data to Microsoft, configure telemetry at the Security level, turn off Windows Defender telemetry and MSRT reporting, and turn off all of these connections.
segment.target: To prevent Windows from sending any data to Microsoft, configure telemetry at the Security level, turn off Windows Defender telemetry and MSRT reporting, and turn off all of these connections.

segment.source: We strongly recommend against this, as this data helps us deliver a secure, reliable, and more delightful personalized experience.

segment.source: 1. Cortana
segment.target: 1. Cortana

segment.source: Use either Group Policy or MDM policies to manage settings for Cortana.
segment.target: Use either Group Policy or MDM policies to manage settings for Cortana.

segment.source: For more info, see Cortana, Search, and privacy: FAQ.
segment.target: For more info, see Cortana, Search, and privacy: FAQ.

segment.source: 1.1 Cortana Group Policies
segment.target: 1.1 Cortana Group Policies

segment.source: Find the Cortana Group Policy objects under Computer ConfigurationAdministrative TemplatesWindows ComponentsSearch.
segment.target: Find the Cortana Group Policy objects under Computer ConfigurationAdministrative TemplatesWindows ComponentsSearch.

segment.source: Policy
segment.target: Policy

segment.source: Description
segment.target: Description

segment.source: Allow Cortana
segment.target: Allow Cortana

segment.source: Choose whether to let Cortana install and run on the device.
segment.target: Choose whether to let Cortana install and run on the device.

segment.source: Allow search and Cortana to use location
segment.target: Allow search and Cortana to use location

segment.source: Choose whether Cortana and Search can provide location-aware search results.
segment.target: Choose whether Cortana and Search can provide location-aware search results.

segment.source: Do not allow web search
segment.target: Do not allow web search

segment.source: Choose whether to search the web from Windows Desktop Search.
segment.target: Choose whether to search the web from Windows Desktop Search.

segment.source: Default: Disabled
segment.target: Default: Disabled

segment.source: Don't search the web or display web results in Search
segment.target: Don't search the web or display web results in Search

segment.source: Choose whether to search the web from Cortana.
segment.target: Choose whether to search the web from Cortana.

segment.source: Set what information is shared in Search
segment.target: Set what information is shared in Search

segment.source: Control what information is shared with Bing in Search.
segment.target: Control what information is shared with Bing in Search.

segment.source: When you enable the Don't search the web or display web results in Search Group Policy, you can control the behavior of whether Cortana searches the web to display web results.
segment.target: When you enable the Don't search the web or display web results in Search Group Policy, you can control the behavior of whether Cortana searches the web to display web results.

segment.source: However, this policy only covers whether or not web search is performed.
segment.target: However, this policy only covers whether or not web search is performed.

segment.source: There could still be a small amount of network traffic to Bing.com to evaluate if certain Cortana components are up-to-date or not.
segment.target: There could still be a small amount of network traffic to Bing.com to evaluate if certain Cortana components are up-to-date or not.

segment.source: In order to turn off that network activity completely, you can create a Windows Firewall rule to prevent outbound traffic.
segment.target: In order to turn off that network activity completely, you can create a Windows Firewall rule to prevent outbound traffic.

segment.source: Expand Computer ConfigurationWindows SettingsSecurity SettingsWindows Firewall with Advanced SecurityWindows Firewall with Advanced Security - LDAP name, and then click Outbound Rules.
segment.target: Expand Computer ConfigurationWindows SettingsSecurity SettingsWindows Firewall with Advanced SecurityWindows Firewall with Advanced Security - LDAP name, and then click Outbound Rules.

segment.source: Right-click Outbound Rules, and then click New Rule.
segment.target: Right-click Outbound Rules, and then click New Rule.

segment.source: The New Outbound Rule Wizard starts.
segment.target: The New Outbound Rule Wizard starts.

segment.source: On the Rule Type page, click Program, and then click Next.
segment.target: On the Rule Type page, click Program, and then click Next.

segment.source: On the Program page, click This program path, type %windir%systemappsMicrosoft.Windows.Cortanacw5n1h2txyewySearchUI.exe, and then click Next.
segment.target: On the Program page, click This program path, type %windir%systemappsMicrosoft.Windows.Cortanacw5n1h2txyewySearchUI.exe, and then click Next.

segment.source: On the Action page, click Block the connection, and then click Next.
segment.target: On the Action page, click Block the connection, and then click Next.

segment.source: On the Profile page, ensure that the Domain, Private, and Public check boxes are selected, and then click Next.
segment.target: On the Profile page, ensure that the Domain, Private, and Public check boxes are selected, and then click Next.

segment.source: On the Name page, type a name for the rule, such as Cortana firewall configuration, and then click Finish.
segment.target: On the Name page, type a name for the rule, such as Cortana firewall configuration, and then click Finish.

segment.source: Right-click the new rule, click Properties, and then click Protocols and Ports.
segment.target: Right-click the new rule, click Properties, and then click Protocols and Ports.

segment.source: Configure the Protocols and Ports page with the following info, and then click OK.
segment.target: Configure the Protocols and Ports page with the following info, and then click OK.

segment.source: For Protocol type, choose TCP.
segment.target: For Protocol type, choose TCP.

segment.source: For Local port, choose All Ports.
segment.target: For Local port, choose All Ports.

segment.source: For Remote port, choose All ports.
segment.target: For Remote port, choose All ports.

segment.source: Note: If your organization tests network traffic, you should not use Fiddler to test Windows Firewall settings.
segment.target: Note: If your organization tests network traffic, you should not use Fiddler to test Windows Firewall settings.

segment.source: Fiddler is a network proxy and Windows Firewall does not block proxy traffic.
segment.target: Fiddler is a network proxy and Windows Firewall does not block proxy traffic.

segment.source: You should use a network traffic analyzer, such as WireShark or Message Analyzer.
segment.target: You should use a network traffic analyzer, such as WireShark or Message Analyzer.

segment.source: 1.2 Cortana MDM policies
segment.target: 1.2 Cortana MDM policies

segment.source: The following Cortana MDM policies are available in the Policy CSP.
segment.target: The following Cortana MDM policies are available in the Policy CSP.

segment.source: Policy
segment.target: Policy

segment.source: Description
segment.target: Description

segment.source: Experience/AllowCortana
segment.target: Experience/AllowCortana

segment.source: Choose whether to let Cortana install and run on the device.
segment.target: Choose whether to let Cortana install and run on the device.

segment.source: Search/AllowSearchToUseLocation
segment.target: Search/AllowSearchToUseLocation

segment.source: Choose whether Cortana and Search can provide location-aware search results.
segment.target: Choose whether Cortana and Search can provide location-aware search results.

segment.source: Default: Allowed
segment.target: Default: Allowed

segment.source: 1.3 Cortana Windows Provisioning
segment.target: 1.3 Cortana Windows Provisioning

segment.source: To use Windows Imaging and Configuration Designer (ICD) to create a provisioning package with the settings for these policies, go to Runtime settingsPolicies to find ExperienceAllowCortana and SearchAllowSearchToUseLocation.
segment.target: To use Windows Imaging and Configuration Designer (ICD) to create a provisioning package with the settings for these policies, go to Runtime settingsPolicies to find ExperienceAllowCortana and SearchAllowSearchToUseLocation.

segment.source: 2. Date & Time
segment.target: 2. Date & Time

segment.source: You can prevent Windows from setting the time automatically.
segment.target: You can prevent Windows from setting the time automatically.

segment.source: To turn off the feature in the UI: SettingsTime & languageDate & timeSet time automatically
segment.target: To turn off the feature in the UI: SettingsTime & languageDate & timeSet time automatically

segment.source: -or-
segment.target: -or-

segment.source: Create a REGSZ registry setting in HKEYLOCALMACHINESYSTEMCurrentControlSetServicesW32TimeParameters with a value of NoSync.
segment.target: Create a REGSZ registry setting in HKEYLOCALMACHINESYSTEMCurrentControlSetServicesW32TimeParameters with a value of NoSync.

segment.source: 3. Device metadata retrieval
segment.target: 3. Device metadata retrieval

segment.source: To prevent Windows from retrieving device metadata from the Internet, apply the Group Policy: Computer ConfigurationAdministrative TemplatesSystemDevice InstallationPrevent device metadata retrieval from the Internet.
segment.target: To prevent Windows from retrieving device metadata from the Internet, apply the Group Policy: Computer ConfigurationAdministrative TemplatesSystemDevice InstallationPrevent device metadata retrieval from the Internet.

segment.source: 4. Font streaming
segment.target: 4. Font streaming

segment.source: Starting with Windows 10, fonts that are included in Windows but that are not stored on the local device can be downloaded on demand.
segment.target: Starting with Windows 10, fonts that are included in Windows but that are not stored on the local device can be downloaded on demand.

segment.source: To turn off font streaming, create a REGDWORD registry setting called DisableFontProviders in HKEYLOCALMACHINESystemCurrentControlSetServicesFontCacheParameters, with a value of 1.
segment.target: To turn off font streaming, create a REGDWORD registry setting called DisableFontProviders in HKEYLOCALMACHINESystemCurrentControlSetServicesFontCacheParameters, with a value of 1.

segment.source: Note: This may change in future versions of Windows.
segment.target: Note: This may change in future versions of Windows.

segment.target: 5. Insider Preview builds

segment.target: To turn off Insider Preview builds if you're running a released version of Windows 10.

segment.target: If you're running a preview version of Windows 10, you must roll back to a released version before you can turn off Insider Preview builds.

segment.source: 6.2 ActiveX control blocking
segment.target: 6.2 ActiveX control blocking

segment.source: ActiveX control blocking periodically downloads a new list of out-of-date ActiveX controls that should be blocked.
segment.target: ActiveX control blocking periodically downloads a new list of out-of-date ActiveX controls that should be blocked.

segment.source: You can turn this off by changing the REGDWORD registry setting HKEYCURRENTUSERSoftwareMicrosoftInternet ExplorerVersionManagerDownloadVersionList to 0 (zero).
segment.target: You can turn this off by changing the REGDWORD registry setting HKEYCURRENTUSERSoftwareMicrosoftInternet ExplorerVersionManagerDownloadVersionList to 0 (zero).

segment.source: 10. Network Connection Status Indicator
segment.target: 10. Network Connection Status Indicator

segment.source: Network Connection Status Indicator (NCSI) detects Internet connectivity and corporate network connectivity status.
segment.target: Network Connection Status Indicator (NCSI) detects Internet connectivity and corporate network connectivity status.

segment.source: NCSI sends a DNS request and HTTP query to http://www.msftncsi.com to determine if the device can communicate with the Internet.
segment.target: NCSI sends a DNS request and HTTP query to http://www.msftncsi.com to determine if the device can communicate with the Internet.

segment.source: For more info about NCIS, see The Network Connection Status Icon.
segment.target: For more info about NCIS, see The Network Connection Status Icon.

segment.source: You can turn off NCSI through Group Policy:
segment.target: You can turn off NCSI through Group Policy:

segment.source: Enable the Group Policy: Computer ConfigurationAdministrative TemplatesSystemInternet Communication ManagementInternet Communication SettingsTurn off Windows Network Connectivity Status Indicator active tests
segment.target: Enable the Group Policy: Computer ConfigurationAdministrative TemplatesSystemInternet Communication ManagementInternet Communication SettingsTurn off Windows Network Connectivity Status Indicator active tests

segment.source: Note After you apply this policy, you must restart the device for the policy setting to take effect.
segment.target: Note After you apply this policy, you must restart the device for the policy setting to take effect.

segment.target: -or-

segment.target: Enable the Group Policy Computer ConfigurationAdministrative TemplatesWindows ComponentsWindows DefenderSignature UpdatesDefine the order of sources for downloading definition updates and set it to FileShares.

segment.source: -and-
segment.target: -and-

segment.source: Enable the Group Policy Computer ConfigurationAdministrative TemplatesWindows ComponentsWindows DefenderSignature UpdatesDefine file shares for downloading definition updates and set it to nothing.
segment.target: Enable the Group Policy Computer ConfigurationAdministrative TemplatesWindows ComponentsWindows DefenderSignature UpdatesDefine file shares for downloading definition updates and set it to nothing.

segment.source: You can also use the registry to turn off Malicious Software Reporting Tool telemetry by setting the REGDWORD value HKEYLOCALMACHINESoftwarePoliciesMicrosoftMRTDontReportInfectionInformation to 1.
segment.target: You can also use the registry to turn off Malicious Software Reporting Tool telemetry by setting the REGDWORD value HKEYLOCALMACHINESoftwarePoliciesMicrosoftMRTDontReportInfectionInformation to 1.

segment.source: 20. Windows Media Player

segment.target: From the Programs and Features control panel, click Turn Windows features on or off, under Media Features, clear the Windows Media Player check box, and then click OK.

segment.target: Run the following DISM command from an elevated command prompt: dism /online /Disable-Feature /FeatureName:WindowsMediaPlayer

segment.source: 22. Windows Store
segment.target: 22. Windows Store

segment.source: You can turn off the ability to launch apps from the Windows Store that were preinstalled or downloaded.
segment.target: You can turn off the ability to launch apps from the Windows Store that were preinstalled or downloaded.

segment.source: This will also turn off automatic app updates, and the Windows Store will be disabled.
segment.target: This will also turn off automatic app updates, and the Windows Store will be disabled.

segment.source: Apply the Group Policy: Computer ConfigurationAdministrative TemplatesWindows ComponentsStoreDisable all apps from Windows Store.
segment.target: Apply the Group Policy: Computer ConfigurationAdministrative TemplatesWindows ComponentsStoreDisable all apps from Windows Store.

segment.source: 23. Windows Update Delivery Optimization
segment.target: 23. Windows Update Delivery Optimization

segment.source: Windows Update Delivery Optimization lets you get Windows updates and Windows Store apps from sources in addition to Microsoft, which not only helps when you have a limited or unreliable Internet connection, but can also help you reduce the amount of bandwidth needed to keep all of your organization's PCs up-to-date.
segment.target: Windows Update Delivery Optimization lets you get Windows updates and Windows Store apps from sources in addition to Microsoft, which not only helps when you have a limited or unreliable Internet connection, but can also help you reduce the amount of bandwidth needed to keep all of your organization's PCs up-to-date.

segment.source: If you have Delivery Optimization turned on, PCs on your network may send and receive updates and apps to other PCs on your local network, if you choose, or to PCs on the Internet.
segment.target: If you have Delivery Optimization turned on, PCs on your network may send and receive updates and apps to other PCs on your local network, if you choose, or to PCs on the Internet.

segment.source: By default, PCs running Windows 10 Enterprise and Windows 10 Education will only use Delivery Optimization to get and receive updates for PCs and apps on your local network.
segment.target: By default, PCs running Windows 10 Enterprise and Windows 10 Education will only use Delivery Optimization to get and receive updates for PCs and apps on your local network.

segment.source: Use the UI, Group Policy, MDM policies, or Windows Provisioning to set up Delivery Optimization.
segment.target: Use the UI, Group Policy, MDM policies, or Windows Provisioning to set up Delivery Optimization.

segment.source: 23.1 Settings Update & security
segment.target: 23.1 Settings Update & security

segment.source: You can set up Delivery Optimization from the Settings UI.
segment.target: You can set up Delivery Optimization from the Settings UI.

segment.source: Go to SettingsUpdate & securityWindows UpdateAdvanced optionsChoose how updates are delivered.
segment.target: Go to SettingsUpdate & securityWindows UpdateAdvanced optionsChoose how updates are delivered.

segment.source: 23.2 Delivery Optimization Group Policies
segment.target: 23.2 Delivery Optimization Group Policies

segment.source: You can find the Delivery Optimization Group Policy objects under Computer ConfigurationAdministrative TemplatesWindows ComponentsDelivery Optimization.
segment.target: You can find the Delivery Optimization Group Policy objects under Computer ConfigurationAdministrative TemplatesWindows ComponentsDelivery Optimization.

segment.source: Policy
segment.target: Policy

segment.source: Description
segment.target: Description

segment.source: Download Mode
segment.target: Download Mode

segment.source: Lets you choose where Delivery Optimization gets or sends updates and apps, including
segment.target: Lets you choose where Delivery Optimization gets or sends updates and apps, including

segment.source: None.
segment.target: None.

segment.source: Turns off Delivery Optimization.
segment.target: Turns off Delivery Optimization.

segment.source: Group.
segment.target: Group.

segment.source: Gets or sends updates and apps to PCs on the same local network domain.
segment.target: Gets or sends updates and apps to PCs on the same local network domain.

segment.source: Internet.
segment.target: Internet.

segment.source: Gets or sends updates and apps to PCs on the Internet.
segment.target: Gets or sends updates and apps to PCs on the Internet.

segment.source: LAN.
segment.target: LAN.

segment.source: Gets or sends updates and apps to PCs on the same NAT only.
segment.target: Gets or sends updates and apps to PCs on the same NAT only.

segment.source: Group ID
segment.target: Group ID

segment.source: Lets you provide a Group ID that limits which PCs can share apps and updates.
segment.target: Lets you provide a Group ID that limits which PCs can share apps and updates.

segment.source: Note This ID must be a GUID.
segment.target: Note This ID must be a GUID.

segment.source: Max Cache Age
segment.target: Max Cache Age

segment.source: Lets you specify the maximum time (in seconds) that a file is held in the Delivery Optimization cache.
segment.target: Lets you specify the maximum time (in seconds) that a file is held in the Delivery Optimization cache.

segment.source: The default value is 259200 seconds (3 days).
segment.target: The default value is 259200 seconds (3 days).

segment.source: Max Cache Size
segment.target: Max Cache Size

segment.source: Lets you specify the maximum cache size as a percentage of disk size.
segment.target: Lets you specify the maximum cache size as a percentage of disk size.

segment.source: The default value is 20, which represents 20% of the disk.
segment.target: The default value is 20, which represents 20% of the disk.

segment.source: Max Upload Bandwidth
segment.target: Max Upload Bandwidth

segment.source: Lets you specify the maximum upload bandwidth (in KB/second) that a device uses across all concurrent upload activity.
segment.target: Lets you specify the maximum upload bandwidth (in KB/second) that a device uses across all concurrent upload activity.

segment.source: The default value is 0, which means unlimited possible bandwidth.
segment.target: The default value is 0, which means unlimited possible bandwidth.

segment.source: 23.3 Delivery Optimization MDM policies
segment.target: 23.3 Delivery Optimization MDM policies

segment.source: The following Delivery Optimization MDM policies are available in the Policy CSP.
segment.target: The following Delivery Optimization MDM policies are available in the Policy CSP.

segment.source: Policy
segment.target: Policy

segment.source: Description
segment.target: Description

segment.source: DeliveryOptimization/DODownloadMode
segment.target: DeliveryOptimization/DODownloadMode

segment.source: Lets you choose where Delivery Optimization gets or sends updates and apps, including
segment.target: Lets you choose where Delivery Optimization gets or sends updates and apps, including

segment.source: 0. Turns off Delivery Optimization.
segment.target: 0. Turns off Delivery Optimization.

segment.source: 1. Gets or sends updates and apps to PCs on the same NAT only.
segment.target: 1. Gets or sends updates and apps to PCs on the same NAT only.

segment.source: 2. Gets or sends updates and apps to PCs on the same local network domain.
segment.target: 2. Gets or sends updates and apps to PCs on the same local network domain.

segment.source: 3. Gets or sends updates and apps to PCs on the Internet.
segment.target: 3. Gets or sends updates and apps to PCs on the Internet.

segment.source: DeliveryOptimization/DOGroupID
segment.target: DeliveryOptimization/DOGroupID

segment.source: Lets you provide a Group ID that limits which PCs can share apps and updates.
segment.target: Lets you provide a Group ID that limits which PCs can share apps and updates.

segment.source: Note This ID must be a GUID.
segment.target: Note This ID must be a GUID.

segment.source: DeliveryOptimization/DOMaxCacheAge
segment.target: DeliveryOptimization/DOMaxCacheAge

segment.source: Lets you specify the maximum time (in seconds) that a file is held in the Delivery Optimization cache.
segment.target: Lets you specify the maximum time (in seconds) that a file is held in the Delivery Optimization cache.

segment.source: The default value is 259200 seconds (3 days).
segment.target: The default value is 259200 seconds (3 days).

segment.source: DeliveryOptimization/DOMaxCacheSize
segment.target: DeliveryOptimization/DOMaxCacheSize

segment.source: Lets you specify the maximum cache size as a percentage of disk size.
segment.target: Lets you specify the maximum cache size as a percentage of disk size.

segment.source: The default value is 20, which represents 20% of the disk.
segment.target: The default value is 20, which represents 20% of the disk.

segment.source: DeliveryOptimization/DOMaxUploadBandwidth
segment.target: DeliveryOptimization/DOMaxUploadBandwidth

segment.source: Lets you specify the maximum upload bandwidth (in KB/second) that a device uses across all concurrent upload activity.
segment.target: Lets you specify the maximum upload bandwidth (in KB/second) that a device uses across all concurrent upload activity.

segment.source: The default value is 0, which means unlimited possible bandwidth.
segment.target: The default value is 0, which means unlimited possible bandwidth.

segment.source: 23.4 Delivery Optimization Windows Provisioning
segment.target: 23.4 Delivery Optimization Windows Provisioning

segment.source: If you don't have an MDM server in your enterprise, you can use Windows Provisioning to configure the Delivery Optimization policies
segment.target: If you don't have an MDM server in your enterprise, you can use Windows Provisioning to configure the Delivery Optimization policies

segment.source: Use Windows ICD, included with the Windows Assessment and Deployment Kit (Windows ADK), to create a provisioning package for Delivery Optimization.
segment.target: Use Windows ICD, included with the Windows Assessment and Deployment Kit (Windows ADK), to create a provisioning package for Delivery Optimization.

segment.source: Open Windows ICD, and then click New provisioning package.
segment.target: Open Windows ICD, and then click New provisioning package.

segment.source: In the Name box, type a name for the provisioning package, and then click Next.
segment.target: In the Name box, type a name for the provisioning package, and then click Next.

segment.source: Click the Common to all Windows editions option, click Next, and then click Finish.
segment.target: Click the Common to all Windows editions option, click Next, and then click Finish.

segment.source: Go to Runtime settingsPoliciesDeliveryOptimization to configure the policies.
segment.target: Go to Runtime settingsPoliciesDeliveryOptimization to configure the policies.

segment.source: For more info about Delivery Optimization in general, see Windows Update Delivery Optimization: FAQ.
segment.target: For more info about Delivery Optimization in general, see Windows Update Delivery Optimization: FAQ.

segment.source: 24. Windows Update
segment.target: 24. Windows Update

segment.source: You can turn off Windows Update by setting the following registry entries:
segment.target: You can turn off Windows Update by setting the following registry entries:

segment.source: Add a REGDWORD value called DoNotConnectToWindowsUpdateInternetLocations to HKEYLOCALMACHINESoftwarePoliciesMicrosoftWindowsWindowsUpdate and set the value to 1.
segment.target: Add a REGDWORD value called DoNotConnectToWindowsUpdateInternetLocations to HKEYLOCALMACHINESoftwarePoliciesMicrosoftWindowsWindowsUpdate and set the value to 1.

segment.source: -and-
segment.target: -and-

segment.source: Add a REGDWORD value called DisableWindowsUpdateAccess to HKEYLOCALMACHINESoftwarePoliciesMicrosoftWindowsWindowsUpdate and set the value to 1.
segment.target: Add a REGDWORD value called DisableWindowsUpdateAccess to HKEYLOCALMACHINESoftwarePoliciesMicrosoftWindowsWindowsUpdate and set the value to 1.

segment.source: You can turn off automatic updates by doing one of the following.
segment.target: You can turn off automatic updates by doing one of the following.

segment.source: This is not recommended.
segment.target: This is not recommended.

segment.source: Add a REGDWORD value called AutoDownload to HKEYLOCALMACHINESoftwareMicrosoftWindowsCurrentVersionWindowsStoreWindowsUpdate and set the value to 5.
segment.target: Add a REGDWORD value called AutoDownload to HKEYLOCALMACHINESoftwareMicrosoftWindowsCurrentVersionWindowsStoreWindowsUpdate and set the value to 5.

segment.source: -or-
segment.target: -or-

segment.source: Apply the Update/AllowAutoUpdate MDM policy from the Policy CSP, where:
segment.target: Apply the Update/AllowAutoUpdate MDM policy from the Policy CSP, where:

segment.source: 0. Notify the user before downloading the update.
segment.target: 0. Notify the user before downloading the update.

segment.source: 1. Auto install the update and then notify the user to schedule a device restart.
segment.target: 1. Auto install the update and then notify the user to schedule a device restart.

segment.source: 2 (default).
segment.target: 2 (default).

segment.source: Auto install and restart.
segment.target: Auto install and restart.

segment.source: 3. Auto install and restart at a specified time.
segment.target: 3. Auto install and restart at a specified time.

segment.source: 4. Auto install and restart without end-user control.
segment.target: 4. Auto install and restart without end-user control.

segment.source: 5. Turn off automatic updates.
segment.target: 5. Turn off automatic updates.

segment.source: To learn more, see Device update management and Configure Automatic Updates by using Group Policy.
segment.target: To learn more, see Device update management and Configure Automatic Updates by using Group Policy.
